keyTakeAways: OpenAI has released new policies for its AI tool Sora 2 in response to widespread concerns from Hollywood studios, unions, and talent agencies about unauthorized use of celebrities' likenesses and intellectual property.
The new policies include an opt-in system allowing individuals and performers to control whether they can be simulated or used in AI-generated content.
OpenAI has agreed to remove AI-generated videos of historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr. and Robin Williams, which were deemed disrespectful or exploitative.

Hollywood talent agencies, including United Talent Agency and Creative Artists Agency, and the union SAG-AFTRA, have publicly criticized the unconsented use of actors' likenesses and are now supporting federal legislation called the 'NO FAKES Act'.
The Motion Picture Association reported that Sora 2 videos have infringed on copyrighted films, shows, and characters, such as in the case of SpongeBob SquarePants cooking illicit drugs.

There is growing concern among artists and performers that AI-generated content reproduces vulnerable or personal aspects of real people without consent, leading to ethical and legal debates about exploitation and artistic integrity.

namedEntities.name: OpenAI
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An artificial intelligence company that developed the Sora 2 tool, which generates realistic video and audio content from text and image prompts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: OpenAI is central to the article as it is the developer of the controversial AI tool Sora 2 that sparked ethical and legal concerns in the entertainment industry.

namedEntities.name: Sora 2
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An artificial intelligence video generation tool developed by OpenAI that allows users to create hyperrealistic audio and video using text and image prompts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sora 2 is the core technology at the center of the controversy, enabling AI-generated content of celebrities, historical figures, and copyrighted characters without consent.

namedEntities.name: Martin Luther King Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A historical civil rights leader whose likeness has been used in unauthorized AI-generated videos, which his estate criticized as disrespectful.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AI-generated video of Martin Luther King Jr. making a negative statement has sparked public outcry, emphasizing the ethical dangers of using real people's likenesses without consent.

namedEntities.name: Robin Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A late actor whose reimagined AI-generated scenes on a park bench were criticized by his daughter, Zelda, as disrespectful and exploitative.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The unauthorized recreation of Robin Williams' persona has highlighted concerns about the dehumanization and misuse of deceased artists' lives and voices in AI content.

namedEntities.name: Zelda Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The daughter of Robin Williams, who publicly condemned AI-generated content of her father, calling it 'horrible slop'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelda's public criticism underscores the emotional and ethical harm caused by unauthorized AI use of her father's identity and legacy.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her statement illustrates the fear among performers that their artistic vulnerability and personal identity could be exploited without consent.

namedEntities.name: SAG-AFTRA

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SAG-AFTRA is a key industry representative pushing for legislation and ethical safeguards against unauthorized AI use of performers' likenesses.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major Hollywood talent agency that has expressed concerns about unconsented AI use of clients' intellectual property.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the first agencies to publicly warn that AI platforms exploiting performers' likeness is a form of exploitation, not innovation.

namedEntities.name: Creative Artists Agency

summaryOfNewsArticle: OpenAI has introduced new policies for its AI video tool Sora 2 in response to widespread ethical and legal concerns raised by Hollywood studios, talent agencies, and unions. The tool allows users to generate hyperrealistic audio and video using text prompts, but has been used to create unauthorized, disrespectful, and exploitative contentâ€”such as AI-generated videos of Martin Luther King Jr., Robin Williams, and SpongeBob SquarePants. These actions have sparked backlash from performers, their families, and rights organizations, who argue that such content violates consent, dignity, and intellectual property. In response, OpenAI has implemented an opt-in policy, blocked public generation of well-known characters, and agreed to remove existing offensive videos. Industry leaders, including SAG-AFTRA, United Talent Agency, and Creative Artists Agency, have joined forces to support the federal 'NO FAKES Act', which would require consent before digital replicas of people can be used. This marks a pivotal moment in the intersection of AI innovation and creative rights, raising urgent questions about consent, exploitation, and the future of artistic expression.
title: Hollywood Pushes OpenAI for Consent
